Abstract

Linagliptin Provides Superior Glycemic Control Compared to Voglibose as Monotherapy in Japanese Patients with Type 2 Diabetes

Year: 2010

Abstract Number: 632-P

Authors: RYUZO KAWAMORI, NOBUYA INAGAKI, EIICHI ARAKI, HIROTAKA WATADA, NAOYUKI HAYASHI, YOSHIHARU HORIE, AKIKO SARASHINA, HANS-JUERGEN WOERLE, KLAUS DUGI

Institutions: Tokyo, Japan, Kyoto, Japan, Kumamoto, Japan, Biberach, Germany, Ingelheim, Germany

Results: This multi-center, 26-wk, randomized, double-blind, active-controlled, parallel group study, compared the efficacy and safety of the DPP-4 inhibitor linagliptin (LI) vs. the α-glucosidase inhibitor voglibose (VB) in drug naïve or previously treated Japanese patients (pts) with T2DM (baseline HbA1c 7.0-10.0% if drug naïve, 7.0-9.0% if previously treated with an oral hypoglycemic agent (OHA)). Following a 2-wk PBO run-in, pts were randomized to LI 5 (n=159) or 10 mg qd (n=160), or VB (0.2 mg tid; n=162). Any previous OHA treatment was stopped 2 wks prior to run-in. Mean baseline [SD] characteristics and demographics (HbA1c, 8.01% [0.68]; fasting plasma glucose (FPG), 163.5 mg/dL [32.4]; BMI, 24.97 kg/m2 [3.86]; age, 60.0 yrs [9.7]) were similar across groups. The primary endpoint was the change from baseline in HbA1c after 26 wks. The differences of adjusted mean changes from baseline in HbA1c at wk 26 were -0.32% for LI 5 mg vs. VB (p=0.0003) and -0.39% for LI 10 mg vs. VB (p<0.0001). Proportions of pts achieving HbA1c <7.0% after 26 wks were 30.2% for LI 5 mg and 34.4% for LI 10 mg vs. 22.2% for VB. Proportions of patients whose HbA1c level lowered by ≥0.5% were 57.2 and 53.5% for LI 5 and 10 mg, vs. 37.7% for VB. FPG was significantly improved with both LI 5 and 10 mg compared to VB: the differences of adjusted mean changes from baseline were -6.9 mg/dL for LI 5 mg vs. VB (p=0.02) and -9.8 mg/dL for LI 10 mg vs. VB (p=0.0015). The occurrence of ≥1 adverse event (AE) was comparable between groups (72.3% LI 5 mg, 77.5% LI 10 mg and 71.6% VB). Of the AEs, 11.3%, 10.6% and 18.5%, respectively, were assessed as drug-related. There were more skin and subcutaneous tissue AEs in LI pts (8.2% 5 mg, 5.6% 10 mg) vs. VB pts (2.5%). Drug-related gastrointestinal disorders were more common in the VB (14.2%) than LI (8.2% 5 mg; 8.1% 10 mg) groups. In the VB group, 1 hypoglycemic episode was reported vs. none in the LI groups. Conclusion: LI monotherapy demonstrated greater efficacy than VB for improving glycemic control in Japanese pts with T2DM and was well tolerated in this population.

Category: Pharmacologic Treatment of Diabetes or its Complications
